title: Stocks climb after Trump promises Oval Office meeting with Chinese negotiator
text:
Stocks climbed on Thursday morning after President Trump disclosed plans for an Oval Office meeting with China's vice premier, spurring speculation that the world's two largest economies are moving closer to a trade deal.

Continue Reading Below

The blue-chip Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.6 percent to 26,493, while the broader S&P 500 and the tech-heavy Nasdaq also gained less than 1 percent. The major averages have been whipped around in recent days amid conflicting reports on the chances of any sort of agreement between the U.S. and Chinese negotiators, who are in Washington for two days of talks.

FOX Business learned on Wednesday that Chinese negotiators could leave Washington after one day. However, White House Deputy Press Secretary Judd Deere issued this statement: “We are not aware of a change in the Vice Premier’s travel plans at this time."

Reports out earlier in the week suggested Beijing could be open to a partial deal, a possibility Trump's tweet backed up.

Shares of the Pacific Gas & Electric plummeted after a U.S. bankruptcy judge ruled that a plan developed by bondholders, led by the hedge fund Elliott Management and supported by California citizens with claims against the utility for damage caused by the wildfire, should be considered. The utility filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in January because of liabilities related to northern California wildfires in 2017 and 2018.

In Asia, Japan's benchmark Nikkei finished the session with a gain of 0.5 percent, Hong Kong's Hang Seng closed up 0.1 percent and China's Shanghai Composite ended the day up 0.8 percent.

In Europe, London's FTSE and Germany's DAX are up less than 1 percent and France's CAC is higher by 0.8 percent.

FOX Business' Ken Martin contributed to this report.
description: Talks on the trade war between the U.S. and China are a focal point for traders.
